{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3555523,"name":"Alexis Lee","username":"TaoTaoBamBam","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/c67d28/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-12T21:31:39.896Z","cooked":"

We have been testing our robot out before our first competition and have run into a couple issues that seem to be regarding a mismatch in the applied and actual voltages.

  1. Swerve: we use an Xbox controller to control the swerve drive of our robot. However, when we move the movement joystick left and right, it moves the robot inconsistently. Sometimes when pressed fully it will not move the robot at all and sometimes the robot will move when pressed fully. Usually the robot will not move when given small inputs. This has been an ongoing issue with the robot this season.

However, it is important to note that the forward and backward movement (up and down on the joystick) works perfectly, and does not have the same issue. The deadbands are the same, and the setups for the slew limiters are also the same, so I’m not sure where this issue originates from.

Also to note, the setpoints and measured values for the swerve modules are pretty much identical, no matter what happens with the joystick.

  1. Elevator: Earlier yesterday the elevator worked perfectly, however today it doesn’t work. There is a disparity in the voltage applied (either through PID or through manual control) and the actual voltage of the motor. When the PID controller wants to apply a voltage of 10-12 volts, the motor will instead read 1 volt, and will not move the elevator up. Using the joystick will apply 0-3 volts, and that works inconstantly as well, sometimes working normally and sometimes not working at all.

Here is the link to our github repository if that is of any assistance (we are currently using the dev branch): GitHub - ultraviolet8567/Reefscape: Robot code for FRC Team 8567 in the 2025 Reefscape season

Thank you so much for any help you guys can give!

Another thing I forgot to mention: the computer is reading the joystick controls correctly.
